unnormalised: ## Yoga Practices: More Than Just Twisting Like Shilpa Shetty in a Song?
normalised: ## Yoga Practices: More Than Just Twisting Like Shilpa Shetty in a Song?

unnormalised: Okay, so let's talk yoga. I've seen enough Bollywood movies where Shilpa Shetty is contorting herself into impossible poses in some far-off Swiss Alps scene to know the *image* of yoga. But what's the real deal?
normalised: Okay, so let us talk yoga. I have seen enough Bollywood movies where Shilpa Shetty is contorting herself into impossible poses in some far-off Swiss Alps scene to know the image of yoga. But what is the real deal?

unnormalised: I started properly looking into it last year, after my doctor, Dr. Sharma from the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), suggested it for my back pain. Honestly, I was skeptical. I thought it was all just chanting and stretching.
normalised: I started properly looking into it last year, after my doctor, Doctor Sharma from the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (A I I M S), suggested it for my back pain. Honestly, I was skeptical. I thought it was all just chanting and stretching.

unnormalised: But it's so much more! I started with a Hatha yoga class near my house in Gurgaon. Initially, I could barely touch my toes! Now, after about 6 months, I can almost do a headstand (still working on it!), and my back pain is significantly reduced.
normalised: But it is so much more! I started with a Hatha yoga class near my house in Gurgaon. Initially, I could barely touch my toes! Now, after about six months, I can almost do a headstand (still working on it!), and my back pain is significantly reduced.

unnormalised: What's surprised me most is the mental clarity. After a session, I feel calmer and more focused. It's not just about the physical postures (asanas) like Surya Namaskar or Trikonasana. Itâ€™s also about the breathing (pranayama) and the mindfulness.
normalised: What has surprised me most is the mental clarity. After a session, I feel calmer and more focused. It is not just about the physical postures (asanas) like Surya Namaskar or Trikonasana. It is also about the breathing (pranayama) and the mindfulness.

unnormalised: I'm still a beginner, exploring different styles like Ashtanga and Vinyasa. Maybe someday I'll be as flexible as Shilpa Shetty...or at least flexible enough to pick up something I dropped without groaning! Anyone else in the early stages of their yoga journey? What have been your experiences? Any tips for a newbie? And does anyone know where I can find a good Iyengar yoga class near Sector 45, Gurgaon?
